com.learning.arrays

Class ArrayFunctions

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.learning.arrays.ArrayFunctions

  • public class ArrayFunctions
extends java.lang.Object

    ArrayFunctions

    The ArrayFunctions.java program covers array related functions like sorting, searching, addition and average

    1.0
    Author:
    Vishal Agarwal

        public static void linearSearchInArray(int[] arr,
                                       java.util.Scanner sc)
        Method will search number in the given array by looking for the element one by one i.e. first it will go to first element then second then third and so on.
        Parameters:

        sc - - Scanner object for the number which is to be found out

      • selectionSortingInArray

        public static void selectionSortingInArray(int[] arr)
        The algorithm works by selecting the smallest unsorted item and then swapping it with the item in the next position to be filled. The selection sort works as follows: you look through the entire array for the smallest element, once you find it you swap it (the smallest element) with the first element of the array. Then you look for the smallest element in the remaining array (an array without the first element) and swap it with the second element. Then you look for the smallest element in the remaining array (an array without first and second elements) and swap it with the third element, and so on Example :
        29, 64, 73, 34, 20,
        20, 64, 73, 34, 29,
        20, 29, 73, 34, 64
        20, 29, 34, 73, 64
        20, 29, 34, 64, 73
        Parameters:
        arr - - Array with values

      • bubbleSortingInArray

        public static void bubbleSortingInArray(int[] arr)
        The bubble sort algorithm works by comparing each item in the list with the item next to it, and swapping them if required. In other words, the largest element has bubbled to the top of the array. The algorithm repeats this process until it makes a pass all the way through the list without swapping any items Example :
        7, 5, 2, 4, 3, 9
        5, 7, 2, 4, 3, 9
        5, 2, 7, 4, 3, 9
        5, 2, 4, 7, 3, 9
        5, 2, 4, 3, 7, 9
        5, 2, 4, 3, 7, 9
        Parameters:
        arr - - Array with values

      • insertionSortingInArray

        public static int[] insertionSortingInArray(int[] arr)
        To sort unordered list of elements, we remove its entries one at a time and then insert each of them into a sorted part (initially empty) Example :
        29, 20, 73, 34, 64
        29, 20, 73, 34, 64
        20, 29, 73, 34, 64
        20, 29, 73, 34, 64
        20, 29, 34, 73, 64
        20, 29, 34, 64, 73
        Parameters:
        arr - - Array with values

      • binarySearchInArray

        public static int binarySearchInArray(int[] arr,
                                      boolean printStatement,
                                      java.util.Scanner sc)
        Binary search is a fast search algorithm with run-time complexity of ÎŸ(log n). This search algorithm works on the principle of divide and conquer. For this algorithm to work properly the data collection should be in sorted form. Binary search search a particular item by comparing the middle most item of the collection. If match occurs then index of item is returned. If middle item is greater than item then item is searched in sub-array to the right of the middle item other wise item is search in sub-array to the left of the middle item. This process continues on sub-array as well until the size of sub-array reduces to zero.
        Parameters:
        arr - - Array with values
        sc - - Scanner object for the number which is to be found out
